Of course all conquerors were by definition cruel. In addition military historians generally think that until very modern times that all invading and occupying armies involved mass rape, torture, and murder in addition to theft. So very cruel. If you mean “how were they different” we have to depend on various reports of the conquered over time, and historical records do show different reactions to different invasions. Probably what makes Mongols rare in the invading army department is their announced policy of killing whole cities if they resisted. Genocides of course are sadly not unique in military history but they did not always occur so it puts Mongol policy in a rare group. Caesar, e.g., committed genocide in France. Comparing numbers of people enslaved, raped, murdered and the like is quite difficult since historical records summarizing battles are notorious for exaggeration. Europeans and Muslims alike did recoil at Mongol policy so perhaps Mongols should be lumped into the worst invaders like Caesar. But Mongols did not treat Europeans differently than others. The “kill all resisting cities” concept was not the common warfare method in the West, where over time in some places having soldiers go fight it out and then go home was a cultural practice for some armies, i.e. killing entire cities often defeated the point of warfare, which was often to capture gold or get the labor of peasants rather than to kill them.
